Typography is all around us

from books to websites, through mobile applications,
we have to deal with written words

Beginners Guide to Typography
Typography can be dated back to the 11th century, during the innovation of movable type.
Typography is the art of

manipulating the visual form of language
to enrich and control its message

Beginners Guide to Typography
Before the digital age, typography was a specialized craft associated with books and magazines, and eventually public works.
Typography is so much more ...

than just choosing beautiful fonts,
it's about guide and convey emotions

Beginners Guide to Typography
The first example of typography can be seen in the Gutenberg Bible, which kick-started a typography revolution in the west.
Typography builds brand recognition

consistent typography will build trust,
and help to carry your brand forward

Beginners Guide to Typography
Fun fact: the style of type used in the Gutenberg Bible is now known as Textura, and you’ll find it in the font drop down menu on major desktop applications today!
Typography influences decision making

an eye-catching typography empowers the message of the text
and is much more persuasive than a weak typography

Beginners Guide to Typography
Fast forward to modern day, where typography is mostly associated with both the digital world and print. With the birth of the internet came a creative explosion of the art of typography.
Typography holds the attention of the readers

good typography could make the difference between
staying 1 min or ½ an hour on your website or product

Beginners Guide to Typography
Suddenly, web designers had an abundance of fonts and type options at their disposal, making typography more visually diverse than ever before.

at the end of the day

Typography is what brings text to life
Statistics
A bare and raw truth
Web Design is 95% Typography

iA Writer blog
link

that's because 95% percent of what we can
develop, read, or interact with
is in written language

How does Typography impacts Developers work?
With great power comes great responsibility
It is certainly not up to us to choose the fonts, but to the Designers

... true, but ...
it is up to us to make sure we're
transposing without transforming
what is provided us by the Designers

Type Face (@font-face)
CSS is our font front door ;-)
A common piece of code to start from
    
      html {
        /* 
          16px/10px = 0.625, expressed in em
          makes the font-size reactive to browser settings
          and makes 1rem = 10px,
          allowing to use rems as a simple division base-10 value
        */
        font-size: 0.625em;      
      }
      
      body {
        font-family: Verdana, sans-serif;
        font-size: 1.6rem;
        line-height: 2rem; 
      }
      
      ...
What does font mean?
it's a single size, weight and style configuration of a typeface
    
      html {
        /* 
          16px/10px = 0.625, expressed in em
          makes the font-size reactive to browser settings
          and makes 1rem = 10px,
          allowing to use rems as a simple division base-10 value
        */
        font-size: 0.625em;      
      }
      
      body {
        font-family: Verdana, sans-serif;
        font-size: 1.6rem;
        font-weight: 400;
        font-style: normal;
        line-height: 2rem; 
      }
      
      ...
... and what does typeface mean?
it's a full family of fonts sharing the same design
A typeface is a particular set of glyphs or sorts (an alphabet and its corresponding accessories such as numerals and punctuation) that share a common design. For example, Helvetica is a well known typeface.
A font is a particular set of glyphs within a typeface.

Hoban Cards
LINK

... and what does typeface mean?
different fonts but same typeface

12pt text

14pt text

14pt italic text

14pt light text

Helvetica

Shouldn't a system font be enough?
there are a lots of system fonts usages around the web, aren't they?
    
      ...
 
      /* System Fonts as used by GitHub */
      body {
        font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, 
          "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol";
      }
      
      /* another approach to achieve the same result */
      @font-face {
        font-family: CustomSystemFonts;
        font-style: normal;
        src: local("-apple-system"), local("BlinkMacSystemFont"), local("Segoe UI"), local("Helvetica"), 
          local("Arial"), local("sans-serif"), local("Apple Color Emoji"), local("Segoe UI Emoji"), 
          local("Segoe UI Symbol");
      }

      body {
        font-family: CustomSystemFonts;
      }
So why should we define a typeface?
most designs are usually based on brand/custom fonts
just think about our customer's brand identity
How can we define a typeface?
@font-face allows us to create our custom font-family
    
      html {
        /* 
          16px/10px = 0.625, expressed in em
          makes the font-size reactive to browser settings
          and makes 1rem = 10px,
          allowing to use rems as a simple division base-10 value
        */
        font-size: 0.625em;      
      }
      
      body {
        font-family: 'CustomFont', FallbackFont, sans-serif;
        font-size: 1.6rem;
        font-weight: 400;
        line-height: 2rem; 
      }
      
      ...
Browsers will try to use the font you specified first (CustomFont, in this case).
If CustomFont is not available, browsers will fallback fonts in the list from left to right.
How can we define a typeface?
@font-face allows us to create our custom font-family
    
      ...
      
      body {
        font-family: 'CustomFont', FallbackFont, sans-serif;
        font-size: 1.6rem;
        font-weight: 400;
        line-height: 2rem; 
      }
      
      @font-face {
        font-family: 'CustomFont';
        src: url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff2') format('woff2'),
          url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff') format('woff');
        font-style: normal;
        font-weight: 400;
      }
      
      ...
by specifying the same font-family in every @font-face definition
we're defining a typeface
How can we define a typeface?
@font-face allows us to create our custom font-family
    
      ...
      
      @font-face {
        font-family: 'CustomFont';
        src: url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff2') format('woff2'),
          url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff') format('woff');
        font-style: normal;
        font-weight: 400;
      }
      
      ...
so a single @font-face definition combines a font glyphs file, a font-style and a font-weight
How can we define a typeface?
@font-face allows us to create our custom font-family
    
      ...
      
      @font-face {
        font-family: 'CustomFont';
        src: url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff2') format('woff2'),
          url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular.woff') format('woff');
        font-style: normal;
        font-weight: 400;
      }
      
      /* font style variation */
      @font-face {
        font-family: 'CustomFont';
        src: url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular-Italic.woff2') format('woff2'),
          url('path/to/CustomFont-Regular-Italic.woff') format('woff');
        font-style: italic;
        font-weight: 400;
      }
      
      ...
(NOTE: be careful, use only fonts you are licensed to use)
How can we use a defined typeface?
it's easier than you think! just specify your desired font variation (style, weight, display)

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                font-family: 'CustomFont';
                font-weight: 100;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                font-family: 'CustomFont';
                font-weight: 300;
                font-style: italic;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                font-family: 'CustomFont';
                font-weight: 500;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                font-family: 'CustomFont';
                font-weight: 900;
              }
Font Scale
https://type-scale.com
What is a Font Scale?
The typographic scale has been used for centuries in traditional typography as a means of creating balanced and harmonious font sizing.
It is the bedrock of modern typography.

Spencer Mortensen blog (2011)
link

aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
A modern approach to font scale
ratio is what we need if we want to achieve good proportions in font scale

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

Paragraph/Plain Text

 
          
            @use 'sass:math';
            
            $font-ratio: 1.25; /* major third 4:5 */
            /* 
              16px/10px = 0.625, expressed in em
              makes the font-size reactive to browser settings
              and makes 1rem = 10px,
              allowing to use rems as a simple division base-10 value
            */
            $font-root: 0.625em;      
            $font-base: 1.6rem;
  
            html {
              font-size: $font-root;
              color: white;
            }
            
            body {
              font-size: $font-base;
              line-height: $font-ratio;
            }
            
            h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, p {
              margin: calc(#{$font-base} * #{$font-ratio}) 0 0;
            }
  
            ...
A modern approach to font scale
combining the powers of SASS variables and CSS calc...

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

Paragraph/Plain Text

 
          
            ...
            
            h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, p {
              margin: calc(#{$font-base} * #{$font-ratio}) 0 0;
            }
  
            h1 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 6)});
            }
  
            h2 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 5)});
            }
  
            h3 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 4)});
            }
  
            ...
A modern approach to font scale
... we will achieve a zoom responsive font scale

Paragraph/Plain Text

 
          
            ...
            
            h3 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 4)});
            }
  
            h4 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 3)});
            }
  
            h5 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 2)});
            }
            
            h6 {
              font-size: calc(#{$font-base} * #{math.pow($font-ratio, 1)});
            }
  
            p {
              font-size: $font-base;
            }
A future approach to font scale
reworking with CSS custom properties...

Heading 5
Heading 6

Paragraph/Plain Text

 
          
            :root {
              --font-ratio: 1.25; /* major third 4:5 */
              /* 
                16px/10px = 0.625, expressed in em
                makes the font-size reactive to browser settings
                and makes 1rem = 10px,
                allowing to use rems as a simple division base-10 value
              */
              --font-root: 0.625em;      
              --font-base: 1.6rem;
            }
            
            html {
              font-size: var(--font-root);
              color: white;
            }
            
            body {
              font-size: var(--font-base);
              line-height: var(--font-ratio);
            }
            
            h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, p {
              margin: calc(var(--font-base) * var(--font-ratio)) 0 0;
            }
            
            ...

* release expected late 2021 or early 2022

            h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, p {
              margin: calc(var(--font-base) * var(--font-ratio)) 0 0;
            }
  
            h1 {
              font-size: calc(var(--font-base) * pow(var(--font-ratio), 6));
            }
            
            h2 {
              font-size: calc(var(--font-base) * pow(var(--font-ratio), 5));
            }
  
            h3 {
              font-size: calc(var(--font-base) * pow(var(--font-ratio), 4));
            }
            
            ...

            }
  
            h5 {
              font-size: calc(var(--font-base) * pow(var(--font-ratio), 2));
            }
            
            h6 {
              font-size: calc(var(--font-base) * var(--font-ratio));
            }
            
            p {
              font-size: $font-base;
            }
Font Stacks
Stacks are groups of different font families
a Design best practice is to use different fonts for different types of content

Fonts: Raleway Bold + Helvetica Neue Condensed Bold

No contrast
Fonts are too similar
Text is hard to read

Fonts: Nunito Sans + Halant

Good contrast
Fonts are well balanced
Text is easy to read

too many fonts can be worse
than using a single one
be careful using this technique

there's a reason why Designers call it font pairing
please use no more than three fonts for your design/implementations

Monospace Fonts
A good practice is also to take care about numbers
just think about currencies and the need to manage a proper alignment in tables

we need a monospace font

A Monospace font has a specific simple feature
all characters have the same width
... do you remember this table?
Tables
# Item Value Quantity
1 Apples 0,30€ 7
2 Lemonade 0,50€ 18
3 Bread 1,00€ 2
4 Potatoes 0,39€ 4
5 Seabass 54,99€ 1
let's see a modern approach about this

unicode-range
allows us to select a specific range of characters of a single font
Tables
# Item Value Quantity
1 Apples 0,30€ 7
2 Lemonade 0,50€ 18
3 Bread 1,00€ 2
4 Potatoes 0,39€ 4
5 Seabass 54,99€ 1 
          
            :root {
              --monospace: 'CustomMonospace', Helvetica, sans-serif;
            }
            
            @font-face {
              font-family: 'CustomMonospace';
              src: local('monospace');
              font-weight: normal;
              font-style: normal;
              unicode-range: U+0030-0039, U+20A3-20A7, U+002C, U+002E;
            }
            
            table {
              font-family: var(--monospace);
            }

              ...
              
              overflow: hidden;
              text-overflow: ellipsis;
            }

will our friend CSS still be awesome?
CSSeses ISeses AWESOME

              ...

Line Clamping
can be your best friend in this case!

Line Clamping
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et, consetetur sadipscing elitr. 
          
            .example {
              --font-size: 2.2rem;
              --line-height: 4rem;
              --lines-to-show: 3;

              display: block; // Fallback for non-webkit
              display: -webkit-box;
              -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
              overflow: hidden;
              text-overflow: ellipsis;

              font-size: var(--font-size);
              line-height: var(--line-height);
              -webkit-line-clamp: var(--lines-to-show);
              line-clamp: var(--lines-to-show);
            
              --max-height: calc(var(--font-size) * var(--line-height) * var(--lines-to-show));
              max-height: var(--max-height); // Fallback for non-webkit
            }

Text Rendering
Font Smoothing

this is a text paragraph

 
                
                  

                    
this is a text paragraph

                  

                
              
                
                  .example {
                    padding: 1rem;
                    border: 0.2rem dashed #dedede;
                    border-radius: 0.8rem;
                    -webkit-font-smoothing: auto; // default
                    -moz-osx-font-smoothing: auto; // default
      
                    p {
                      font-size: 2rem;
                      line-height: 1;
                    }
                  }
Font Smoothing

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Turns font smoothing off
                // Displays text with jagged sharp edges
                -webkit-font-smoothing: none;
                -moz-osx-font-smoothing: none;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Smooth the font on the level of the pixel
                // For light text on dark backgrounds makes it look lighter
                -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // On non-retina displays text will be sharper
                // (the risk is to have fonts looking a bit bolder)
                -webkit-font-smoothing: subpixel-antialiased;
                -moz-osx-font-smoothing: greyscale;
              }
Font Kerning

Kerning disabled

Kerning enabled

In typography, kerning is the process of adjusting the spacing between characters in a proportional font, usually to achieve a visually pleasing result. Kerning adjusts the space between individual letterforms, while tracking (letter-spacing) adjusts spacing uniformly over a range of characters.
Font Kerning

paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Font Kerning is disabled
                font-kerning: none;
              }

paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Font Kerning is enabled
                font-kerning: normal;
              }
            
          
        
          .example {
            // Browser determines if font-kerning should be used or not.
            // Some browsers will disable kerning on small fonts,
            // since applying it could harm the readability of text.
            font-kerning: auto;
          }
Text Spacing
Letter Spacing

this is a text paragraph

 
          
            

              
this is a text paragraph

            

          
        
          
            .example {
              padding: 1rem;
              border: 0.2rem dashed #dedede;
              border-radius: 0.8rem;
              letter-spacing: normal; // default
              
              p {
                font-size: 2rem;
                line-height: 1;
              }
            }
Letter Spacing

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Font Kerning information in the font
                // will be applied
                letter-spacing: normal;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Defines an extra space between characters
                letter-spacing: 0.5rem;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Negative values are allowed
                letter-spacing: -2px;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Portions of pixels are allowed
                letter-spacing: 0.75px;
              }
Word Spacing

this is a text paragraph

 
          
            

              
this is a text paragraph

            

          
        
          
            .example {
              padding: 1rem;
              border: 0.2rem dashed #dedede;
              border-radius: 0.8rem;
              word-spacing: normal; // default
              
              p {
                font-size: 2rem;
                line-height: 1;
              }
            }
Word Spacing

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Defines normal space between words
                // (default: 0.25em)
                word-spacing: normal;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Defines an extra space between characters
                word-spacing: 1rem;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Negative values are allowed
                word-spacing: -4px;
              }

this is a text paragraph

 
            
              .example {
                // Portions of pixels are allowed
                word-spacing: 1.75px;
              }
Text Alignment
Text Align

this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. 

          
            

              

                this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
                consectetur adipiscing elit. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor.
              

            

          
        
          
            .example {
              padding: 1rem;
              border: 0.2rem dashed #dedede;
              border-radius: 0.8rem;
              text-align: initial; // default: left if ltr, right if rtl
                
              p {
                font-size: 2rem;
                line-height: 1;
              }
            }
Text Align

this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.

 
            
              .example {
                // Aligns the text to the left of its fixed width (if specified)
                // or parent element's width (default if ltr)
                text-align: left;
              }

this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.

 
            
              .example {
                // Centers the text within of its fixed width (if specified)
                // or parent element's width
                text-align: center;
              }

this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.

 
            
              .example {
                // Aligns the text to the right of its fixed width (if specified)
                // or parent element's width (default if rtl)
                text-align: right;
              }

this is a longer text paragraph. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.

 
            
              .example {
                // Stretches the lines so that each line has equal width
                // (like in newspapers and magazines)
                text-align: justify;
              }

Vertical Align

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the top of the tallest element
                // on the line
                vertical-align: top;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is placed in the middle
                // of the parent element
                vertical-align: middle;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the lowest element
                // on the line
                vertical-align: bottom;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the baseline 
                // of the parent element. (default)
                vertical-align: baseline;
              }
Vertical Align

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the subscript baseline
                // of the parent element
                vertical-align: sub;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the superscript baseline
                // of the parent element
                vertical-align: super;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the top
                // of the parent element's font
                vertical-align: text-top;
              }

this is a text paragraph. this is a span

 
            
              .example span {
                // element is aligned with the bottom
                // of the parent element's font
                vertical-align: text-bottom;
              }

Variable Fonts
Variable fonts are an evolution of the OpenType font specification that enables many different variations of a typeface to be incorporated into a single file, rather than having a separate font file for every width, weight, or style.

MDN Web Docs
link

Variable Fonts
hi there! i'm breathing ;-)
Variable Fonts

this is a great text example
<>|"£€$%&/()=\'^[]@#¶,;.:-_!? 

              
                .example {
                  --font-var--size: 3rem;
                  --font-var--height: 1.2;
                  --font-var--mono: 0.5;
                  --font-var--casual: 0;
                  --font-var--weight: 400;
                  --font-var--slant: 0;
                  --font-var--cursive: 0;
            
                  font-family: var(--font-family--variable--rec-vf);
                  font-size: var(--font-var--size);
                  font-variation-settings: 
                    'MONO' var(--font-var--mono), 
                    'CASL' var(--font-var--casual),
                    'wght' var(--font-var--weight), 
                    'slnt' var(--font-var--slant), 
                    'CRSV' var(--font-var--cursive);
            
                  line-height: var(--font-var--height);
                }
